speakername: The MINISTER OP RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: Is there an estimate of what the total cost of this work will be ?
We have only expended $225,000 out of the $600,000 which it was originally estimated we would require.
speakername: The MINISTER OP RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: Is this work done by contract and tender ?
Invariably.
speakername: The MINISTER OP RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: Who are the principal contractors?

The Hamilton Bridge Company; the Canadian Bridge Company; the Montreal Bridge Company; the bridge companies who do that kind of work are invited to tender.
Increased accommodation at Ldvis, $22,000.
speakername: The MINISTER OP RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: Does any of this money go for the land which has been the subject of an action in the Exchequer Court ?
There is nothing in this vote to pay for land. I believe that litigation is still pending.
speakername: The MINISTER OP RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: What is this money for ?
To grade the yard; to complete the track laying; to provide for a water service; to build a concrete walk; for sidewalks alongside of the tracks; for a wooden covering.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext:
I was in Quebec a few months ago, and from the Quebec side I saw a balloon like structure of wood, something like what would be erected in a mushroom town. It appeared to be a regular fire trap. Surely the minister is not putting up a wooden structure at Levis. I am not



3S12
finding fault with the expenditure, but it did seem to me to be a most unsuitable structure, judging by the appearance from the other side of the river.
I do not know that my hon. friend (Mr. Osier) is speaking of the station that is in course of erection at Levis. The description he has given would not suggest it to my mind.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: I asked what it was and they told me that it was the Intercolonial Railway station.
Will the minister furnish us at a later stage with similar information with regard to Levis that he promised with regard to Sydney as to the total cost, and so on ?

Yes.
Additional sidings along the line, $50,000.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: Is it the intention of the minister to make any improvement in the sidings at Apohaqui ?
We have not made any provision for Apohaqui.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: The necessary improvement there would only cost a very small sum, and it is greatly required in consequence of the amount of business done there. The siding should be extended. It is now only possible to load four cars at a time. To give an idea of the extent of business done there, I may say that this year between the 1st of January and the 1st of July there will be shipped about five million feet of lumber besides a very large quantity of tan bark and cord wood. I think some little improvement was about to be made this spring to the through siding, but the other requires to be lengthened and graded. I will furnish the minister with a plan which I have had prepared showing the improvements that are necessary.

We might possibly be able to do something in connection with that in the supplementary estimates, but it is a long and tedious job to get these items extended. We have to spread them over years, and we take first those for which there is the most urgent need. I will note what the hon. gentleman has said, and will see what can be done.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: The minister will see from the number of cars of lumber shipped this year the amount of business, and it will not diminish in the near future. For the want of this improvement shippers are caused a great deal of inconvenience and expense.
I know that the trouble is serious.	'
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: I suppose the minister will give us a list of these sidings. If he will lay it on the Table with the other papers, we will not delay the item.

I will do so.
To exchange drawbars of freight cars, $3.5,009.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: Are these the master car builders' drawbars ?

They are.
New machinery for locomotive and car shops,
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

Hon. members can understand that in having to handle heavier cars and locomotives we require heavier machinery, and we are endeavouring to supply that need as rapidly as we can.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: What class of machinery?
It is the ordinary machinery required for handling our locomotives and cars in the workshop.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: Perhaps the hon. gentleman will give us a 'statement showing the kind of machinery.

I will try to do so.
To equip 10 passenger cars with Pintsch gas apparatus, $8,000.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

I think not. I think we ought to be able to complete all of them by next year.
New superstructure for six spans Mirimichi bridge, $51,000.

speechtext: I make the same objection to the whole of this charge being made to capital that I did with regard to steel rails. This is for substituting a new superstructure for an old one. and the amount should be less by a proper charge to maintenance as regards the old superstructure.
Is there any estimated charge to maintenance, as in the case of other railways ?
We are transferring this bridge to the Island Railway. So far as weight goes it is a first class bridge.

Yes. There will be no profit between the two.

We are valuing the old bridge at .832,000, as a bridge for the Prince Edward Island Railway.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: W'hat about the old bridge on Prince Edward Island ?

There is no old bridge. This is entirely new.
Rolling stock, Intercolonial Railway, $500,000.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: The present system is entirely wrong. Just fancy this new master mechanic being engaged here for some months and not knowing the condition of the rolling stock of the road. Why should it not be the duty of the master mechanic to see that the hundreds of cars which are laying by, some of which require very little repairs, are repaired instead of buying new cars ?
The cars that are worth repairing are repaired.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: Not according to the evidence.

The repairs may possibly be deferred owing to pressure of work. I do not know that the hon. gentleman Is in any position to condemn the mechanical superintendent. It would be an injustice to any officer to iset him aside in that off-hand way as incompetent. This mechanical superintendent was formerly in the service of the Grand Trunk Railway as assistant to the chief mechanical superintendent and is a very bright man, and I shall be disappointed if he does not turn out exceedingly capable. But I would not expect him to be able in a few months to do work which, under ordinary conditions, would require a great deal longer. I ask the hon. gentleman to suspend judgment. No political aim can be served by his laying the weight of his condemnation on this young man who has done remarkably well up to the present. I found him very reliable as far as I could judge. One of the first things I asked him to do was to make up a schedule and prepare a scheme governing the wages and employees and the grading of employees in the shops. It was a new thing, but this gentleman ap-1201
plied himself to it at once with energy, and worked out a scheme that seems to have met with very general approval. I was well pleased with the work this young man has done. I endeavoured to get his predecessor interested in the work, but he did not seem able to take it up. This young man, however, took it up and dealt with it very satisfactorily.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: I have not made any remarks for the purpose of belittling the mechanical superintendent. My sole object was to improve the working of the Intercolonial Railway. So far as this young man is concerned, I believe he is a practical man, but I am taking the statement he made at the committee. When asked whether he had examined all the cars, he said no, but he looked at some.
How was it physically possible?
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: He saiid why it was he had not the other cars examined. It was because he was not directly concerned in them, but was more concerned in anything he undertook since engaged by the government. Just as that young man said, these cars are automatically reported to the department, and those not requiring large repairs would naturally be repaired at the shops, but I understand in this instance there was a large number that require very little repair. Why should not the government repair these old cars and charge them to maintenance instead of buying new ones ?
We require additional cars as well.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: You are having cars lying around now, which the government is getting no service out of. It is for these reasons that the Intercolonial Railway is not economically managed. The hon. gentleman asked to-night how we would save expenditure ? In the first place, you should not buy three times more ties than are necessary, nor, should you have cars lying by idle when a little repairing would make them lit for use. Unless you can economically conduct your road, you are not going to make any money out of it. There is a large number of cars lying to one side, which could be used with very little repairs, according to the evidence of this young man, and why, they should not be used is more than I can understand.

In addition to the cars which have been referred to, which are capable of repair, there are 364 condemned cars. Those cars ought to be replaced out of capital. They are never going into service again, and it is absurd to go on pretending to work them. They are set down in the hon. gentleman's stock list as 364 condemned cars and remaining condemned to 1st July, 1901. The hon. gentleman should

replace those cars out of his revenue account. He must keep up his stock. Instead of charging the whole of this .$500,000 to capital account, he ought to charge 364 cars to maintenance and the excess go to capital. Mr. Mulilfeld, the new mechanical superintendent, told me that from 25 to 30 locomotives were so worn that they could not be used economically. They should also be replaced before the hon. gentleman charges another locomotive to capital.

I think my hon. friend must be referring to a number of cars which we got a great many years ago and which have been condemned for years, and have not been replaced in the ordinary way at all. They were coal dumping cars of an old pattern-short boxes with small hoppers- which have gone out of use.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: Mr. Muhlfeld says that there are 25 or 30 locomotives on the line which are so old that they cannot be used economically. These should be sold to some contractors for $1,000 a piece and the money credited to revenue, and they should be replaced at the charge of revenue. No auditor of an ordinary railway company would allow him to charge one locomotive to capital until he had done that.

We turn out of our shops or are buying on maintenance from six to nine of these big locomotives a year, so we are doing more in the way of getting new locomotives on maintenance account then was formerly done.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: The hon. gentleman is buying twenty-six on capital account.
But the others were played out years ago.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: What difference does that make ?

Does the hon. gentleman say that it is fair that I should take the accumulation of cars and locomotives that were out of date before I came into the department and replace them on maintenance ac-cunt, and so swell the maintenance account away beyond the appropriation of the year ?
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: The hon. gentleman made the same defence last year. WThen I was referring to his condemned cars, the hon. gentleman asked me if I had taken the trouble to look at the state of the rolling stock account when he took the line over. I said that I had and gave him the figures for every year, and showed him that he had more than doubled the number of condemned cars. He had at the beginning of last year, and during the year, over 500 condemned cars, and although he replaced some he still left 364 on the condemned list.

With the enormous growth of the business and with the limited capacity of our shops, it is impossible to keep up. I am in hopes that we are approaching the time when, with these appropriations we shall be able to get this work off our hands as the demands arrive.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: The hon. minister has said that the former mechanical superintendent did not seem to be able to prepare a schedule of wages as it has been prepared by the gentleman who now fills that position. I would like to know if the former mechanical superintendent ever received instructions to prepare a schedule covering the whole number of men employed in the shops.

I had a good many conversations with the former mechanical superintendent, and had not a word of complaint to make. I did not think he took hold of the idea with the same promptness that the present man has done. That is all I said.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: What proportion of this sum is for cars, for locomotives and for passenger coaches ?
It is all for locomotives-twenty-five at $20,000 a piece.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: And all to be built at the Kingston Locomotive Works, none in the United States ?

No. I want to assure my hon. friend that there has not been a single locomotive ordered or purchased or built in the United States for us when the Kingston Locomotive Works have been in such a state of operation as to be able to undertake to carry out our contracts.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: So far as I am concerned, that assurance is perfectly useless, for I maintain that years ago we should have placed ourselves in the same position as every other great railway in this country and had our locomotives built here. So, the hon. minister need not give me that assurance with the idea that it will produce any change of conviction in my mind. I say we should have had our locomotives built here' ever since we had the Intercolonial Railway.
How would the hon. gentleman propose to do that ?
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: Like the Canadian Pacific Railway and the Grand Trunk-build locomotives. Why not ? There is no reason.

When the late Hon. Alexander Mackenzie was Minister of Railways and Public Works he established at

Moncton machinery for the construction of engines and locomotives. But, as soon as the change of government took place these works were practically dismantled, and they ceased to do any such work. That was a complaint for years against the government of the day after 1878. Mr. Mackenzie started out with the idea that the Intercolonial Railway would build its own locomotives. He did build excellent locomotives, and they stand there today, monuments to his good judgment, and to the good work that was done at Moncton. I think that recently there has been an attempt to renew these works.

It is high time that this kind of argument, this tu quoque argument, should cease. It is getting a little old. What have we to do with what was done by Alexander Mackenzie and by those who immediately succeeded him? Nothing whatever But we have a right to ask the government to adopt the same policy in one department as in another. The Minister of Public Works requires dredges and many other things to carry on the deepening of the St. Lawrence, and he establishes works at Sorel in order to have these things constructed in our own country. Our contention is that the same thing should be done in the case of the Department of Railways and Canals. But the answer that is given us is that Mr. Mackenzie established locomotive works and that those who came in after him, some of whom I have never seen or known, destroyed his work. That is a strange argument in the mouth of hon. member for Westmoreland (Mr. Emmerson.)

1 confess that my hon. friend (Mr. Monk) surprises me, and I am unable to understand precisely the object of his remarks ? A moment ago, when I made the statement I did, the hon. gentleman in a sort of contemptuous way, said I need not press any such argument upon him because it made no impression upon his mind. Of course. I must submit in all humility, but I can only conclude that the hon. gentleman's mind is not open to access by reason or common sense. Does the hon. gentleman think that, coming into the department in the latter part of the year 1896, and requiring locomotives and which could not be built at Moncton, I was not compelled as a matter of duty to go out of the country to ],uy those locomotives when I could not get them here ? Apparently, the hon. gentleman thinks that I ought to be able to improvise by a breath a complete equipment of shops and everything ready to turn out locomotives.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: When did the hon. gentleman begin ordering those locomotives in the States ?

The first locomotive we ordered
was in 1897. I could not get any appropriation until the end of the session of 1897. Would it be reasonable for me, or .could I justify myself in advising my colleagues and parliament to spend enough money at Moncton to manufacture engines and turn them out in the time we required them. All we needed to do was to keep renewing and repairing, which would not require works of anything like the same magnitude as to turn out 100 locomotives in three or four years. Our works are large enough to turn out seven, or eight or ten locomotives a year.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: They must be very small shops.

A locomotive a week is a pretty good production. I do not know whether the Kingston works were ever able to turn out more than one locomotive a week. But one thing is clear, it was utterly impossible for me to get locomotives except by going to the United States for them.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: Did the hon. gentleman buy any during the last fiscal year ?
No, except what we got from the Kingston works.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: Have there been any cars purchased in the States during the last year ?

None. A statement was made by the ex-minister of railways (Hon. Mr. Haggart)-I am sorry he is not here-that only one locomotive was bought by him. He was referring to an incident that occurred before the Public Accounts Committee about locomotives being condemned by this circular that was issued, when it came out that some of those locomotives were made in the United States in the year 1S93. The hon. gentleman denied it and said there was only one, and it was got from the Cooke Locomotive Works. The reason, he said, why he did not get any from Kingston was that the Kingston works were shut down. I said that when this item was up I would furnish some evidence to show that the hon. gentleman was mistaken. I have before me a certificate from Mr. Bir-kett, the secretary treasurer of the Canadian Locomotive and Engine Company, and he certifies that the above statement is correct, and that the works at Kingston were going continuously from 18S8 until the liquidators closed them in September, 1900. He says there was a large amount of jobbing done, besides making locomotives, and several marine engines were made. He commences his statement with 1888, and gives the output of the locomotive works from that year down to 1893. I need not particularize every year. The point I want to make is that the locomotive works were in actual operation

at Kingston at the very period the hon. gentleman went to the Cooke concern to procure locomotives.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: As the hon. member for Lanark (Mr. Maggart) is not present, would the minister read the number of locomotives purchased in each year.

In 1SS8 they turned out 16 : in 1899, 10 ; 1890, 28 ; 1891, 12 ; 1892 26 * 1893, 2 ; 1894, 11 ; 1895, 3 ; 1896, 3 ; 1897, 4 1898, 4 ; 1899, 5 ; and under the reorganized management in 1900, 36.
29, the Portland Locomotive Works 11, the Danforth Locomotive Works 4, the Hinckley Locomotive Works 9, the Rhode Island Locomotive Works 5, the Cooke's Locomotive Works of Paterson, New Jersey, 2. They were the two that were got in 1893, and the Dubs Locomotive Works furnished 15. Two of the Grant, six of the Manchester, and one of the Danforth engines were furnished before 1875.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: - Does that include the eight locomotives you got from the Manchester and Richmond locomotive works ?
In 1893 there were only 2 ? *

Only 2 turned out. The hon. gentleman went to the United States for locomotives and declined to take those he could have got from the Kingston works. I have a letter or two here which perhaps may throw a little light on that subject. Mr. Lee, who is the mechanical man in charge of the Kingston works, wrote as early as April 15, 1893, to the department stating that he had received the specifications of the two locomotives that were required, and he says that he will ' mail an offer for those two locomotives on the 17th of April if possible, on the 18th of April, at the latest.' Then I have a copy of the specifications. On the 9th of May, 1893, I see Mr. Pottinger wrote to this effect :
I have your letter dated May G, with reference to the locomotives. The matter has not yet been settled. It is now being considered by the department at Ottawa.
So they were able to furnish locomotives. Mr. Lee writes again to know whether they would take the two locomotives, and he is advised that the department has not yet settled the matter. Apparently when it was settled, it was against giving the order. I have a letter dated in August, written by Mr. Birkett, secretary treasurer, to the late Minister of Railways and Canals, in which he complains about the delay. He says he would like to have an opportunity of building those, and ' owing to the depression in the United States a number of men have returned out of work, and we could offer them work on a government contract,' and so on. They came from Cooke's. I have here also a memorandum which shows that instead of there being only one such purchase made, there was quite a number. The Kingston works commenced operation I think in 1875, perhaps in 1S73 ; I see where they furnished locomotives in 1875 to the government. I find a statement of the number of locomotives purchased from the time the Kingston works commenced operations don n to the advent of the present government. and the total number bought in the United States was 91. The Grant Locomotive Works of Paterson, New Jersey, furnished 15, the Manchester Locomotive Works
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: I do not think the Richmond locomotive works were established at the time these were got.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: Does that include the locomotives which you got last year ?
No it does not include what we got. This is up to the time that we came in. It does not include what we got since we came in.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: How many locomotives have been purchased by this government since 1S96 ?

I would not like to say off hand. As soon as the Kingston locomotive works were got in operation, under the reorganization, we gave them an order for twenty locomotives, and we have given them two orders of twenty-five each, which would be seventy, speaking from memory. I would not want to be exactly precise about that. I think likely we must have got thirty-five or forty, perhaps, in the United States.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext:
It'seems to me that this might have been foreseen and it seems to me a very poor answer to give when a wrong is pointed out or a fault indicated to say that the same thing was necessary under the previous administration. I was given to understand before I came into this parliament that the previous administration had been a very bad one. If that is to be the rule and at a certain time we come into power we can always point to something these hon. gentlemen have done as an excuse for what we do ourselves, and it would be a very easy way to get out of many difficulties. It seems to me that since we have been purchasing seventy-five or more locomotives in the United States not counting what we have purchased here since 1896, it would be well worth while to consider whether it would not be better to place this railway on the same footing as other great roads in Canada are, on the same footing for instance as the Grand Trunk Railway and the Canadian Pacific Railway.
If it be true, as I have no doubt it is, as the hon. member for Westmoreland (Mr. 3821	APRIL 29, 1902	3822
Emmerson) lias stated, that Mr. Mackenzie had established locomotive works at Moncton, surely it cannot be very hard, with the extensive works I have seen there when I passed, to carry on locomotive works, and it would be much more satisfactory to do the work ourselves. It must be more profitable since this is the system resorted to by the other railways in this country.
The Canadian Pacific Railway are buying sixty or eighty locomotives today.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: They have locomotive works at Montreal and they are constructing locomotives year after year and so are the Grand Trunk Railway.
And so do we.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: You are constructing locomotives ?
Yes, from start to finish.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: Where ?
At Moncton-since we came in.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: How long has this been carried on ?

In 1896 they resumed the construction of locomotives. The works have been enlarged and I quite agree with the hon. member for Jacques Cartier (Mr. Monk) that the works might be still further enlarged in that direction. They have been greatly enlarged and they are doing more construction work there now. But, it must be remembered that with the extension of the Intercolonial Railway the repairs are greater than they were and they want more room. The original works, as established by Mr. Mackenzie and Mr. Brydges, in their day, must necessarily be more crowded to-day than they were then. There would necessarily require to be some extension of the works if the government enter into the construction of locomotives to a greater extent than at present. I quite agree with what the hon. gentleman has stated. I think it would be well for the hon. Minister of Railways and Canals to inquire into the matter as to whether the construction works should not be enlarged at that point. I do not speak from a sectional standpoint merely because Moncton is situated in the constituency I have the honour to represent, but it seems to me that in view of the character of the locomotives constructed in former years at Moncton, of their excellence and durability, it would be well that the works should be enlarged and that this work should be extended.

I understood from the hon. member for Westmoreland that we did not
construct locomotives and I understood the same thing from the hon. minister. I thought the works which had been erected for that purpose at Moncton had been demolished. That was the expression used by the hon. gentleman.
Dismantled, or dismembered.
How many locomotives were turned out at Moncton last year ?
I would not like to commit myself as to how many were turned out last year, but I will ascertain the number. Four or five were turned out last year or the year before.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: Were the works dismembered ?

No, they weire not dismembered in the sense that they could not be used at all. We had to repair our locomotives but the works were not equipped for anything more than the necessary repairs to the locomotives as they came in. That would be my judgment about it.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: I think that all you did in 1901 was to repair locomotives.

Perhaps that may be all we did in 1901. I do not want to be positive. But,
I have a very distinct recollection of being told that we had turned out four or five engines in one year. Perhaps it was in the year before last. But, I will get that information. My hon. friend will see that in view of the urgent necessity there was of meeting the demands upon us, we were asking parliament for very large sums of money and we could not ask for an unlimited vote, we could not give priority to the enlargement of the locomotive works for the making of locomotives when we could get these elsewhere and use the money that parliament would be willing to vote for the necessary purposes of handling the traffic. We could buy locomotives, but if we had put the money into the form of more buildings, machinery and plant and left these necessary services unprovided for, hon. gentlemen would have had good reason to censure me if I had advised that course and my colleagues if they had adopted it.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext:
I do not want to prolong the discussion, but I must confess that I am very much impressed with the idea that our expenditures upon this road in 1900, would have been much wiser if we had installed proper locomotive shops at Moncton or elsewhere. The minister must not forget that in 1900 we bought 1,300,000 ties, when the most we ever used in a year on that railway was 500,000; that we purchased 1,300,000 tons of coal, when the most we ever used in a year was 500,000 tons; and
3S23

that the purchases of stores in that year were enormous. Out of that immense amount of money which seemed to have been expended uselessly, we might have equipped proper locomotive works in Moncton, tvhere we could have puilt those engines ourselves, instead of even depending on Kingston, and especially saving us from going to the United States. In spite of what the minister said the other day ; that I do not represent public opinion in the province of Quebec or in the city of Montreal, I can assure him that it is the sincere belief of the people of my province and of the city of Montreal that the expenditure on this railway is not directed as it should be.
Mr.^ BENNETT. This vote is intended for 25 locomotives at an average price of $20,000 each ?
Yes.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: How is this price arrived at ? Were specifications prepared in the department and submitted to other locomotive concerns ?

We are getting these locomotives made on what may be called the standard specification for that weight of engines. They are practically the same class as are being made in the United States. We asked the prices from different manufacturing companies-and that was before the trust was organized too-and after getting prices we offered the Kingston works a contract for the number of locomotives we required. Our information led us to agree upon the price of $20,270 each.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: The minister forgets that that famous telegram was the only negotiation.
What famous telegram ?
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: The telegram that was sent to Kingston ordering these locomotives. .
The minister paid $20,000 to_the Kingston works, when they only paid $15,000 for the standard locomotives bought in the States.

The practice of all railway companies is to replace one locomotive with another. They do not go into the fine points of putting the cost of one against the cost of another.
